pros: Nothing good to say here.

pros: There are no pros working here.
cons: Upper management is a joke. They lack professionalism. It doesn't make sense how they obtained their positions in management when they lack education and respect towards employees. They just want employees to exploit and treat poorly. Beware if you are young, they are scared you might "take their job". TOO MUCH GOSSIP, it's embarrassing truly for middle aged adults.

job_title: Behavioral Health Clinician in Chicago, IL
pros: Initially Erie was an amazing place to work. They were flexible. The pay was a little low compared to other FQHC’s but was worth it for the peace of mind and flexibility, but after about 1 year or so things changed drastically
cons: No written or set policies and procedures on daily job related tasks. Rules change a lot in a short period of time, and how the communicate the changes is via meetings (again nothing in writing). Very hard to keep up with all the verbal changes and emails of changes then you get written up for “you didn’t follow that rule” Which one out of the last 10 that you changed? And the HCO of Waukegan- Jesus, he is a terrible human being who is a bully and harasses his employees

pros: Great atmosphere dedicated staff and hears employees concerns.
cons: Salary doesn’t match workload and burn out is inevitable

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Chicago, IL
pros: It’s a good place to work at and get experience

Your hard work doesn’t get acknowledged 
Managers want you to work like robots

job_title: IT Support Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros:
Patient Care. Employees. COVID-19 response. Experience. Social Activism. Community outreach. Team building. Employee education. Experience of family. HRis actively looking to hire well qualified people and is seeking to compensate their new hires well.. COVID-19 bonus.

I wrote three paragraphs of amazing, emoji filled praise for the care and support staff, the physicians, the nurses, the ma's supervisors, the board of directors that we are lucky to have., Erie's leadership.... and my phone battery ran out. I hope to post more because the people here are amazing.

The love Erie puts into their mission is second to none. The all star staff and alumni is as well.
cons:
Basically what everyone else is saying in reviews you read about the show in IT, excluding one new extremely well qualified IT contractor who refuses to come on as an employee. I wonder why.... 

The team actively sabotages their own staff by withholding readily available technology,  failing to prioritize the uptime of mission critical infrastructure, and keeps information necessary to support Erie's mission secret because they feel they can and because they don't like you. One quote I heard was it's not the technology let's not tell them they need more employees. Let them figure it out themselves.

It's not our job to be nice was another...... We got all these laptops from a grant from another Dept's COVID-19 budget and we will still decide to whom and when they will be deployed to. Something to that effect. I can't remember. It was shady regardless. 

A popular name that was tossed around about a previous employee that was also ditched amid complaints of abuse and was investigated by the same people was often referred to him in derogatory terms I can't print here.  Other employees were referred we referred to in pseudo swear by C suit IT leadership

I was interrupted while I was explaining to my teammate that my aunt and uncle were terminally ill. I was later then jokingly asked to provide a picture next to her at her funeral as proof. 

One of my best friends was shot in the face and murdered. I was asked what kind of friends I had. 

One week ago. I informed my new manager I was having personal problems, and felt suicidal. Prior to this I had also filed an official complaint that was never investigated. Including with details of my mental illness, depression, and trauma at Erie caused by my teammates, and my direct supervisor. All of whom I'd informed of my situation during my first couple years at Erie. Their first direct employment action after my last disclosure  didn't take place until a week later which was in response to something they found more pressing which was to fire me and bribe me with unemployment, and give me a week of health insurance. Meanwhile I'm bipolar, need my therapist, and my medication more than ever. I can't do anything right now, and I've already been hospitalized once for 10 days. 

I hope Erie follows up on my documentation, and my claims. 

Glass door says keep writing. But I'm tired and I need to close this one for now.

pros: you get to work from home

job_title: Senior Executive Assistant to Chief Executive Officer in Chicago, IL
pros: great working environment and potential for growth.
cons: Pay scale not accurate for all employees

review_title: I have lost faith in non-profits. In one word? Bureaucratic.
pros: You get to work in one of the leading community health centers in the city of Chicago. It gives you a unique look into a larger community health center operation.
cons:
Erie puts a huge emphasis on promoting from within-- which is great, but senior management fails to see how managers supervise their employees. Work morale is low, there is little respect between managers and employees, and communication between the two is strained. Upper management takes their power very seriously, and there is little interaction between them and clinical staff.
Support for staff is low and there is little recognition for a job well done.

job_title: Health Promotion Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: I enjoy the work environment. The people are friendly, professional, positive, patient (when you are new) and supportive. It's quiet and peaceful, which is why I enjoy the environment. My employees are nice too! I like how the departments have a get together to focus on our progress and goals to make our professional goals clear. I don't feel annoyed, frustrated, or angry when I go to work.
cons: I don't like how your sick days and personal days are seen as the same type of days. For a health center, it does not make sense to me that your sick days and personal days are seen as the same type of days. There were days that I genuinely did not feel well. As someone who recently graduated, you need the money. Erie does not provide a competitive salary, or pay rate. I guess the trade off is the work environment.

review_title: It had been good. I have learned a lot but I don't like that they don't train well enough. You basically learn as you go
job_title: Patient Benefit Advocate in Chicago, IL
pros: Working with the patients is one of the best qualities at Erie. The relationships and bonds you create are one of a kind.
cons: Gossip in the work place, management always trying to control your every move and tension in the work place.

pros: They look legitimate and good walking in the door but when you really see the bigger picture it's downhill from there.
cons: Their training techniques are ridiculous and completely unorganized. They never have a yes or no answer to anything. Everyday is guesswork and you are made to feel inferior to everyone else when you ask questions.

pros: This is an organization that tries to do some good in the world.
cons:
Business Intelligence here is awful.  Truly an absolute joke.

It consists of users submitting blind requests into a portal and at some random time in the future, someone will write and execute a query, paste the results into Excel and email it out.  SSRS - a product Microsoft considers to be "long in the tooth" - would be a huge advancement for this place.

I was recruited to upgrade the completely, totally manual processes that underlie business intelligence here.  What I received was absolute reluctance by every single member of the team I supervised.  In fact, I would instruct them to do or not do certain things to try to change how things were done because there were more efficient ways of replicating results in the future and I was routinely ignored by literally every member of the team.  The team just didn't want to change and refused to.

With the organization as a whole, trying to introduce new tools such as SSRS or Power BI instead of the completely manual existing processes...don't expect much at all.  It just doesn't want to change.  My last week there, I had a discussion with a member of senior leadership who was berating me about "changing everything" during a discussion about a project.  Two days later, she told me via email "this is great"...with the only change being that I used Excel Power Query instead of my team spending an hour finding, running and delivering results.  The organization as a whole is basically clueless as far as potential of business intelligence, and doesn't want to learn about the possibilities.

I'm going to toss in a quick note about the backhanded office politics here as well.  There are a bunch of people with have the letters MPH after their name.  They truly think they know everything, including business intelligence.  Good luck dealing with them.

pros: Great coworkers, good learning experience and has fun events.
cons: Management is horrible at Erie Foster. The management is Inexperienced. They are not fair, no support, rude. Front desk supervisor is extremely unprofessional. Benefits are not good, raises are unfair.

review_title: What is happening to staff retention and moral?
pros: Great patients and great clinical team
cons: Too many sites, not enough staff. Overworked and not compensated for all the hard work. The company is more focused on profit rather than health.No holiday bonus and sick hours come out of PTO

job_title: Bilingual WIC Nutritionist in Chicago, IL
pros: Erie as an organization does a very good job of providing healthcare and services to the low income  population of Chicago and it is very rewarding to be a part of that.
cons: Management is not always transparent and can be fickle. There is not a lot of room for growth within my position.

pros: You are helping patients who truly need help, but the challenges caused by management in the Accounting, Finance, and Financial Planning & Analysis make working there difficult.
cons: There is no training in the Accounting, Finance, and Financial Planning & Analysis departments. You either swim or drown. Management in these departments talk negatively behind people’s backs and don’t offer solutions other than firing people. Needless to say, their turn over is high.
